pullRequest.body:
This creates the folder `CategoryTheory/Topos` and the file `CategoryTheory/Topos/Classifier.lean`. The proposed code includes the definition of what it means to be a subobject classifier in a category `C` with a terminal object, and relevant basic results about such a category. This is done in the "internal" sense, for the purpose of eventually defining what it means for a category to be a topos utilizing this definition; see also [#21269](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21269).

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [d6d744ab04](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21281/commits/d6d744ab04827ee6f138c913eabff606b734bfc6)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Topos.Classifier` (new file)|600|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Classifier`
`+ HasClassifier`
`+ comm`
`+ isPullback_χ`
`+ isRegularMonoCategory`
`+ reflectsIsomorphisms`
`+ reflectsIsomorphismsOp`
`+ truth`
`+ truthIsRegularMono`
`+ unique`
`+ Ω`
`+ χ`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Note that the reason for not putting this in the folder `CategoryTheory/Subobject` is precisely because it uses the "internal" definition. A future extension of this content will be to define `CategoryTheory/Subobject/Classifier.lean` and show that the "external" definition of a subobject classifier (that the `Sub` functor is representable) is equivalent.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13509194439/job/37745665379)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13509194439/job/37745665620)
I'm happy with the maths here, just style and naming questions now. We briefly discussed how the limit assumptions should be set up, I think we agreed that the one here is sensible for now?

```suggestion
lemma isPullback : IsPullback m (terminal.from U) (χ_ m) (t C) :=
```

Should this be a `simp` lemma?
```suggestion
@[reassoc]
lemma comm : m ≫ (χ_ m) = terminal.from _ ≫ t C := (pullback m).w
```
Even if it shouldn't be a simp lemma (I'm not quite sure myself yet), it should definitely be `reassoc` as Joël suggests
Upon making this change, the linter is angry about `comm_assoc` not having a docstring, but that lemma was presumably autogenerated. How can I fix this?
Fixed the linter problem, but leaving this open in case a decision is made about making it a `simp` lemma. For now, it is `reassoc` but it is not `simp`.
Presumably, this should be removed, because we can use the `IsPullback` API.
Similarly for the next two declarations
OK, I will remove this content. I think this was a holdover from when I was in the weeds trying to prove the results in `Exponentials.lean`.
I would think we should make `balanced_opposite` an instance.
Is the suggestion that this be named as `Classifier.balancedOpposite`, or that it be removed?
The general fact that `C` balanced implies Cᵒᵖ` should be made an instance, so that the instance in `Classifier.lean` could be removed (as it would be inferred automatically).
I see, this is more clear to me now. Should that change be made in a separate PR before this content is merged?
You may do this `1`-line change in this PR.
Understood. I've just pushed this change.
It looks like `balanced_opposite` is used elsewhere. Is it OK to change it to an `instance` without changing the snake case naming?

Should this be an instance?
```suggestion
theorem reflectsIsomorphisms (D : Type u₀) [Category.{v₀} D] (F : C ⥤ D) [Functor.Faithful F] :
```
These have been renamed and also changed to be instances.

It is usually easier to have this written not using `Unique`, instead for this class to have three fields. One gives the function from `m` to `χ`, the second shows that this function makes the pullback square as you expect, and the third shows it is unique as such (ie any other `χ'` making the pullback square is the same as `χ`)

That is what I had originally. I refactored at the suggestion of someone else over Zulip chat, but will defer to you. Is there plenty of precedent elsewhere in mathlib for this kind of class being written in the way you suggest?
Ah, in fact this should be a structure rather than a class! The best example here is to look at how `IsLimit` is defined: it has `lift`, `fac` and `uniq`.
This refactor is done.
Since my version of the code, `Has` predicates are now all prop-valued, and should only say that a classifier exists, rather than saying what it actually is. See HasTerminal for an example.
Okay, I will refactor the names. That won't be too hard.

Sorry, I should have been clearer here - that wasn't my intention! Instead, I meant that `HasClassifier` should exist, but should be the claim that a classifier exists, rather than saying what it is. Note that this is a departure from what it meant in my version of the code, since the meaning of `Has`- classes has changed since then.

OK, I've made `HasClassifier`. Let me know if this is as you intended. It would also maybe be possible to refactor to remove the class `Classifier C` entirely, but that feels like it would over-complicate things. Let me know what you think.
It seems to me we should keep only `IsClassifier` and `HasClassifier`.

Could you give a little more guidance on how to do that? If `HasClassifier` has to be a Prop, how do I go about referencing `Ω` and `t`? I can do the following, but it seems a little silly: 
```
/-- A category `C` has a subobject classifier if there is at least one subobject classifier. -/
class HasClassifier : Prop where
  /-- There is some classifier. -/
  exists_classifier : ∃ (Ω : C) (t : ⊤_ C ⟶ Ω), Nonempty (IsClassifier t)
```
This seems ok to me. (Arguably, `IsClassifier` should be renamed `Classifier` because it contains data...)
Would it make sense for you to include `t` as a field of the structure `(Is)Classifier` rather than a variable?

Oh, that seems reasonable. However, it now seems like the rest of the content might need to become noncomputable, because assuming this new `HasClassifier` means to access all the fields from a particular `Classifier C` I'll have to make a choice of classifier. Is that OK? Or should I just, in the rest of the file, have some tuple of variables satisfying `Classifier C` (previously `IsClassifier t`)? It seems like the former will be easier when restructuring other files, but I don't want to make large chunks of code noncomputable without double-checking.

I've decided after reading over more of the `CategoryTheory` folder and similar kinds of definitions that it is not really an issue that this is noncomputable content. The main thing that seems to need doing is to rename some of the abbreviations to indicate that they are now choices (using `Nonempty.some`).
Please let me know if there is any issue with the above assessment.

I would suggest defining the structures/classes `Classifier/HasClassifier` as `CategoryTheory.MonoClassifier` and `CategoryTheory.HasMonoClassifier` (or `HasSubobjectClassifier`?). Then, the API definitions and lemmas should probably go in the namespace `CategoryTheory.HasSubobjectClassifier`.
Should the file also be renamed to `MonoClassifier.lean` then?
Is there a reason for these names? They seem confusing to me - classifier and subobject classifier are the usual ways to refer to this, but mono classifier is significantly less common.

The point is to delineate the content of the file from a classifier of terms of type `Subobject B` for `B : C`. That would be an extensional version of this content, and while the data would be equivalent, this content doesn't make any reference to "subobjects" as they are defined in mathlib.

I don't really buy this argument - the object as we've defined it here does classify subobjects, indeed morphisms `X ⟶ Ω` are in bijection with terms of type `Subobject X`. 
I agree the content doesn't make reference to subobjects, but the connection is still there.

That's fair. Maybe this is just overthinking on my part. Would it be acceptable to revert the file name to `Classifier.lean`, the struct to `CategoryTheory.Classifier`, and the class to `CategoryTheory.HasClassifier`? Or would you prefer the term "subobject" go in some/all of those names?
That sounds reasonable to me, but let's maybe double-check with Joël to save you going back-and-forth some more.
Yes, this is good for me.
This is in the root namespace. It should be in `CategoryTheory`.
Of course, sorry. Fixed.

```suggestion
* `HasClassifier.balanced` shows that any category with a subobject classifier
```

```suggestion
* if `m : U ⟶ X)` is a monomorphism, `χ_ m : X ⟶ Ω C` denotes characteristic map of `m`.
```

```suggestion
* `CategoryTheory.HasClassifier C` says that there is at least one
  subobject classifier. `Ω C` denotes a choice of subobject classifier.
```
`RegularMono` contains data. I would suggest defining a `IsRegularMonoCategory` instance instead.

Agreed that this is much better. With an instance of `IsRegularMonoCategory`, the instance `Balanced C` can be removed due to `balanced_of_strongMonoCategory` being an instance. Thanks for pointing this out!

```suggestion
  Ω : C
```

```suggestion
instance reflectsIsomorphismsOp (D : Type u₀) [Category.{v₀} D]
    (F : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ D) [Functor.Faithful F] :
```
Hmm, I wonder if we can give a better name than `t` here. Can we do `true`?  Or maybe `truth`, to avoid clashing with Bool (even though this one does correspond to Bool.true!)

More generally I think we should mimic the namespacing here from how specific limits are set up. eg the equalizer of f g : X -> Y is written `equalizer f g`, and the map `equalizer f g -> X` is written `equalizer.ι`. So maybe, instead of having `characteristicMap` and an abbrev for it, we should have `classifier.χ`.
It has been renamed from `t` to `truth`.
Also, the suggested change for `characteristicMap` is done.

```suggestion
lemma comm : m ≫ χ_ m = terminal.from _ ≫ t C := (isPullback m).w
```

```suggestion
lemma isPullback_χ : IsPullback m (terminal.from U) (χ_ m) (t C) :=
```

```suggestion
instance reflectsIsomorphismsOp (D : Type u₀) [Category.{v₀} D] (F : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ D) [Functor.Faithful F] :
```
if this fits on one line, if not
```suggestion
instance reflectsIsomorphismsOp (D : Type u₀) [Category.{v₀} D] (F : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ D) 
    [Functor.Faithful F] :
```
(or maybe F.Faithful works?)

Looking at my version again, I notice that I didn't assume that the domain here is terminal, since that's actually implied by the other parts. As such, in my development of subobject classifiers, there are no limit assumptions. I wonder if we want to do the same here?

Yes, but your code assumes that the truth morphism is a monomorphism. That's necessary to prove that your `Ω_0` is terminal. This implementation takes the other approach, assuming that `Ω_0` is terminal and proving that truth is a monomorphism.

I see - I missed that difference. It's not totally obvious to me which one is better, so I'm happy to go with your formulation, but let's maybe add a comment somewhere about this choice. (It would also be nice to have a constructor, in a different PR, which allows constructing a classifier from a truth mono and not a terminal object, so people who do prefer the other version can work with this one too).

A comment has been added above `Classifier` regarding this distinction. I agree that there should be a way of constructing a classifier given truth as a mono and an arbitrary object, rather than "the" terminal object. I'll save it for another PR.

The second sentence in this paragraph seems confusing to me. If you intend to prove that the classifier represents `B = >Subobject B`, then I think this should appear in a TODO section by the end of the file's docstring.
Good catch, that sentence was a holdover from when the name was `MonoClassifier`. It's removed now. Please let me know if the new TODO section seems reasonable.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory): Define subobject classifier

source.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Subobject): add formalization of subobject classifier

nodes.body:
Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
